private link i'm sure many of you have heard as well because it's been around for a long time it's a critical piece of what makes aws so flexible
what privately can do is establish a single virtual network that spans your
on-premise data center as well as a vpc within aws and again remember vpc a virtual private cloud is
kind of your own private part of aws and it is a security boundary
through which you know you can set rules that say what kind of traffic can go through this vpc what has access to what what can see what
but the idea is that you can take that vpc and you can make machines and services within the vpc visible to
your on-premise network and vice versa and the great thing about pr the the private link is that it does this
by leveraging the aws global network and you you'll you hear us talking about the global
network a lot but it's really because it's so critical to everything we do uh by being on the global network your
traffic is not routed through the public internet for the most part right i mean obviously has to go to
to exchange for the first hop where it might co-mingle with some uh public internet traffic but in a lot
of cases the rest of the route is traveling over the amazon global network backbone which means that you get two key
benefits one you get much more reliable and faster performance the the network
is is optimized for carrying massive amounts of data and it can do so without ever subjecting
it to the usual you know like like packet sniffing snooping or if a particular exchange goes down
you're unaffected your services continue to run right so especially when you hear a lot of really big customers out there saying
like oh we have a private network to do this we have a private network to do this often that is powered by the amazon

and from that lambda function and the request response travels over our private network backbone
